#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Soshihiro Satake
#Text=Antonio Satake , born Soshihiro Satake , [ 2 ] was a Japanese -born Brazilian martial artist and teacher .
#Text=One of the teachers of Brazilian martial artist Luiz França , [ 3 ]
#Text=together with Geo Omori and Mitsuyo Maeda , Satake was one of the primary founders of Brazilian jiu-jitsu ( BJJ ) . [ 4 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=He pioneered judo in Brazil , the United Kingdom , and other countries . [ 6 ]
#Text=Biography

#Text=Satake started fighting as a sumo wrestler , then he joined the Kudokan dojo academy and competed in judo and jujutsu for Kanō Jigorō , the founder of judo , and for the Kodokan institute . [ 4 ]
#Text=With Mitsuyo Maeda , Satake formed the head of the second generation of Kodokan judoka , which had replaced the first by the beginning of the 20th century . [ 7 ]
#Text=Satake , at 175 centimetres ( 69in ) and 80 kilograms ( 180lb ) , was unmatched in amateur sumo but admitted that he himself was not able to match Maeda in judo . [ 7 ]
#Text=At that time , there were few graduated Kodokan judoka .
#Text=Maeda and Satake were the top graduated professors at Waseda University , both sandan ( 3rd dan ) , along with Matsuhiro Ritaro ( nidan or 2nd dan ) and six other shodan ( 1st dan ) . [ 8 ]
#Text=In 1903 , a senior Kodokan instructor named Yamashita Yoshitsugu traveled to the United States at the request of the Seattle businessman Sam Hill .
#Text=In Washington , DC , Yamashita 's students included Theodore Roosevelt and other prominent Americans .
#Text=At Roosevelt 's request , Yamashita also taught judo at the US Naval Academy . [ 9 ]
#Text=Capitalizing on the publicity , the Japanese Legation in the USA asked the Kodokan to send more judo teachers to America , providing continuity to Yamashita 's work .
#Text=Tsunejiro Tomita reluctantly accepted the task ; Maeda and Satake embraced the opportunity . [ 10 ]
#Text=Tomita , Maeda , and Satake sailed from Yokohama on 16 November 1904 , and arrived in New York City on 8 December 1904 . [ 2 ] [ 11 ]
#Text=Before traveling to Europe , Maeda and Satake went to Cuba along with Akitaro Ono and Tokugoro Ito .
#Text=All of them engaged in combats . [ 12 ]
#Text=On 8 February 1907 , Maeda and Satake arrived in Liverpool , England .
#Text=Apparently they had planned to join up with Akitaro Ono , who had gone to London to wrestle for promoter William Bankier in London music halls . [ 11 ]

#Text=During September 1909 , a Japanese calling himself ' Nobu Taka ' arrived in Mexico City for the purpose of challenging Maeda for what the Mexican Herald said would be the world jujutsu championship . [ 13 ]
#Text=After several months of public wrangling , Taka and Maeda met at the Colon Theater on November 16 , 1909 ; Taka won . [ 14 ]
#Text=There was an immediate rematch , and four days later , Maeda was pronounced the champion . [ 15 ]
#Text=It was later revealed that Taka was , in fact , Soishiro Satake .
#Text=During 1911 , Maeda and Satake were joined in Cuba by Akitaro Ono and Tokugoro Ito .
#Text=The four men were known as the ' Four Kings of Cuba . ' [ 12 ]
#Text=The Four Kings were very popular in Cuba , and the Japanese media were proud of the reputation they were bringing to judo and Japan . [ 16 ]
#Text=In 1913 Maeda and Satake went to El Salvador , Costa Rica , Honduras , Panama , Colombia , Ecuador and Peru .
#Text=In El Salvador , the president was assassinated while they were there , and in Panama , the Americans tried to pay Maeda to lose , and , in response , they kept moving south .
#Text=In Peru they met Laku , a Japanese jujutsuka who taught the military , and invited him to join them .
#Text=They were then joined by Okura in Chile , and by Shimitsu in Argentina .
#Text=The troupe arrived in Porto Alegre on 14 November 1914 . [ 11 ] [ 17 ] [ 18 ] and then moved throughout the country for a year .

#Text=On 26 August 1915 , Maeda , Satake , Okura , Shimitsu , and Laku were at Recife , during October 1915 , they were in Belém , finally arriving in Manaus in the Brazilian state of Amazonas on 18 December 1915 .
#Text=Tokugoro Ito arrived some time later .
#Text=On 20 December 1915 , the first demonstration in Belém took place at the Theatro Politheama .
#Text=The O Tempo newspaper announced the event , stating that Conde Koma would show the main jiu-jitsu techniques , excepting the prohibited ones .
#Text=He would also demonstrate self-defense techniques .

#Text=After that , the troupe would be accepting challenges from the crowd , and there would be the first sensational match of jiu-jitsu between Shimitsu ( champion of Argentina ) and Laku ( Peruvian military professor ) . [ 19 ]

#Text=On 22 December 1915 , according to O Tempo , jiu-jitsu world champion Maeda , head of the Japanese troupe , and Satake , New York champion , performed an enthusiastic and sensational jiu-jitsu match .
#Text=On the same day , Nagib Assef , an Australian Greco-Roman wrestling champion of Turkish origin , challenged Maeda . [ 19 ]
#Text=On 8 January 1916 , Maeda , Okura , and Shimitsu boarded the SS Antony and left for Liverpool .
#Text=Tokugoro Ito went to Los Angeles . [ 20 ]
#Text=Satake and Laku stayed in Manaus teaching , according to O Tempo , jiu-jitsu .
#Text=After 15 years together , Maeda and Satake had finally split up . [ 11 ] [ 19 ]
#Text=Of this last trip to Europe , little is known .
#Text=Maeda went from England to Portugal , Spain , and France , coming back to Brazil in 1917 alone . [ 19 ]
#Text=Satake would become the founder , in 1914 , of the first historically registered judo academy in Brazil .
#Text=He and Maeda are considered the pioneers of judo in Brazil . [ 7 ]
#Text=In January 1916 , Satake won the first jiu-jitsu tournament in the Amazon . [ 2 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=In Manaus
#Text=Satake opened his own academy in 1916 , at the Atlético Rio Negro Clube , which became the first Japanese to open a judo and jiu-jitsu academy in Brazil . [ 2 ] [ 4 ]
#Text=Satake became a Brazilian citizen and changed his name to Antônio Soshihiro Satake . [ 4 ]
#Text=On 19 September 1921 , Satake , Maeda , and Okura were briefly in New York City .
#Text=They were aboard the Booth Line steamship SS Polycarp .
#Text=All three men listed their occupations as professors of " juitso " . [ 21 ]
#Text=After leaving New York , the three men went to the Caribbean , where they stayed from September to December 1921 .
#Text=In Havana , Satake and Maeda took part in some contests .
#Text=Their opponents included Paul Alvarez , who wrestled as Espanol Icognito .
#Text=Alvarez defeated Satake and Yako Okura — the latter being billed as a former instructor at the Chilean Naval Academy — before being himself beaten by Maeda .
#Text=Maeda also defeated a Cuban boxer called Jose Ibarra , and a French wrestler called Fournier . [ 22 ]
#Text=In 1922 , Satake embarked to Europe and nothing was known about him after that . [ 2 ] [ 5 ]
